chapter14.title: Guna Traya Vibhaga Yoga (The Yoga of the Three Gunas)
chapter14.description: In Chapter 14, Krishna explains the three gunas—sattva (goodness), rajas (passion), and tamas (ignorance)—their characteristics, influence on human behavior, and role in binding the soul to material existence. He teaches how to transcend them through devotion and knowledge to attain liberation. For Arjuna, this knowledge helps him understand his emotions and motivations, enabling him to perform his warrior duties with detachment, free from the gunas’ sway.

slok1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम्। यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः।।14.1।।
slok1.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam, yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ
slok1.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: I shall again declare the supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, knowing which all the sages have attained supreme perfection from here.
slok1.explanation: Krishna introduces the supreme knowledge of the three gunas, which leads to liberation, as attained by sages. This sloka sets the chapter’s focus on transcendent wisdom. For Arjuna, this knowledge is vital to navigate the war’s emotional challenges, enabling him to act with clarity and detachment, aiming for spiritual perfection beyond the battlefield.

slok2.sanskrit: इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः। सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च।।14.2।।
slok2.transliteration: idaṁ jñānam upāśritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ, sarge ’pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca
slok2.meaning: By taking refuge in this knowledge, they attain My nature; they are not born at creation nor disturbed at dissolution.
slok2.explanation: Krishna explains that this knowledge aligns one with his divine nature, freeing them from rebirth and dissolution’s distress. This sloka emphasizes liberation through understanding. For Arjuna, this assures that understanding the gunas will liberate him from the war’s material entanglements, enabling him to fight as a soul aligned with Krishna’s divine essence.

slok3.sanskrit: मम योनिर्महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम्। सम्भवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत।।14.3।।
slok3.transliteration: mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbhaṁ dadhāmy aham, sambhavaḥ sarva-bhūtānāṁ tato bhavati bhārata
slok3.meaning: My womb is the great Brahma (Prakriti); in it, I place the seed; from that, O Bharata, arises the birth of all beings.
slok3.explanation: Krishna describes Prakriti as the cosmic womb and himself as the seed-giver, causing all creation. This sloka introduces the gunas’ role in creation. For Arjuna, this clarifies that the war’s warriors and events stem from Krishna’s interaction with Prakriti, urging him to act with detachment, recognizing their divine origin.

slok4.sanskrit: सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः। तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिर्गर्भदः पिता।।14.4।।
slok4.transliteration: sarva-yoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ, tāhāṁ brahma mahad yonir ahaṁ garbha-daḥ pitā
slok4.meaning: In all wombs, O son of Kunti, whatever forms arise, the great Brahma (Prakriti) is their womb, and I am the seed-giving father.
slok4.explanation: Krishna reiterates that all forms of life arise from Prakriti as the mother and himself as the father. This sloka emphasizes the divine source of all beings. For Arjuna, this perspective reveals the war’s participants as divine creations, encouraging him to fight without attachment, seeing all as part of Krishna’s cosmic play.

slok5.sanskrit: सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसम्भवाः। निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्।।14.5।।
slok5.transliteration: sattvaṁ rajas tama iti guṇāḥ prakṛti-sambhavāḥ, nibadhnanti mahā-bāho dehe dehinam avyayam
slok5.meaning: Sattva, rajas, and tamas—these gunas born of Prakriti bind the imperishable soul to the body, O mighty-armed.
slok5.explanation: Krishna introduces the three gunas—sattva (goodness), rajas (passion), and tamas (ignorance)—stating they bind the eternal soul to the body. This sloka establishes the gunas’ binding nature. For Arjuna, understanding how gunas influence his emotions helps him detach from their sway, enabling him to fight as a free soul, not bound by material impulses.

slok6.sanskrit: तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्। सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ।।14.6।।
slok6.transliteration: tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt prakāśakam anāmayam, sukha-saṅgena badhnāti jñāna-saṅgena cānagha
slok6.meaning: Of these, sattva, being pure, is illuminating and healthy; it binds through attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.
slok6.explanation: Krishna describes sattva as pure and illuminating, binding the soul through attachment to happiness and knowledge. This sloka details sattva’s characteristics. For Arjuna, sattva may inspire clarity in battle, but its binding nature warns him to transcend even this guna, fighting with wisdom beyond attachment to happiness or knowledge.

slok7.sanskrit: रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम्। तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम्।।14.7।।
slok7.transliteration: rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛṣṇā-saṅga-samudbhavam, tan nibadhnāti kaunteya karma-saṅgena dehinam
slok7.meaning: Know rajas to be of the nature of passion, born of desire and attachment; it binds the soul through attachment to action, O son of Kunti.
slok7.explanation: Krishna characterizes rajas as passion-driven, binding the soul through desire and action. This sloka explains rajas’ restless nature. For Arjuna, rajas may fuel his warrior zeal, but its binding quality urges him to transcend desire-driven actions, performing his duties with detachment to avoid entanglement in the war’s outcomes.

slok8.sanskrit: तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्। प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत।।14.8।।
slok8.transliteration: tamas tv ajñāna-jaṁ viddhi mohanaṁ sarva-dehinām, pramāda-ālasya-nidrābhis tan nibadhnāti bhārata
slok8.meaning: Know tamas, born of ignorance, to be deluding all embodied beings; it binds through heedlessness, laziness, and sleep, O Bharata.
slok8.explanation: Krishna describes tamas as ignorance-based, binding through delusion, laziness, and sleep. This sloka outlines tamas’ obstructive nature. For Arjuna, tamas may manifest as doubt or lethargy in battle, urging him to overcome it by cultivating sattva and transcending all gunas, ensuring his warrior duties are performed with clarity and purpose.

slok9.sanskrit: सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जनति रजः कर्मणि भारत। ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जनत्युत।।14.9।।
slok9.transliteration: sattvaṁ sukhe sañjanati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata, jñānam āvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde sañjanaty uta
slok9.meaning: Sattva attaches to happiness, rajas to action, O Bharata, while tamas, veiling knowledge, attaches to heedlessness.
slok9.explanation: Krishna explains how each guna attaches the soul: sattva to happiness, rajas to action, and tamas to ignorance and negligence. This sloka clarifies their effects. For Arjuna, this helps identify how gunas influence his war-related emotions—happiness, zeal, or doubt—urging him to transcend them to act as a liberated soul, focused on Krishna.

slok10.sanskrit: रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत। रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा।।14.10।।
slok10.transliteration: rajas tamaś cābhibhūya sattvaṁ bhavati bhārata, rajaḥ sattvaṁ tamaś caiva tamaḥ sattvaṁ rajas tathā
slok10.meaning: Sometimes sattva prevails, overcoming rajas and tamas, O Bharata; sometimes rajas prevails over sattva and tamas, and sometimes tamas over sattva and rajas.
slok10.explanation: Krishna describes the dynamic interplay of gunas, where one dominates at different times. This sloka highlights their fluctuating influence. For Arjuna, this explains his shifting emotions in war—clarity, passion, or doubt—urging him to recognize these as guna-driven and strive to transcend them, performing duties with steady devotion to Krishna.

slok11.sanskrit: सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते। ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत।।14.11।।
slok11.transliteration: sarva-dvāreṣu dehe ’smin prakāśa upajāyate, jñānaṁ yadā tadā vidyād vivṛddhaṁ sattvam ity uta
slok11.meaning: When the light of knowledge shines through all the gates of the body, then it is known that sattva is predominant.
slok11.explanation: Krishna states that sattva’s dominance is marked by knowledge and illumination through the senses. This sloka describes sattva’s symptoms. For Arjuna, moments of clarity and wisdom in battle indicate sattva, but he must transcend even this to avoid attachment, ensuring his warrior actions are offerings to Krishna, free from guna influence.

slok12.sanskrit: लोभः प्रवृत्तिः आरम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा। रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ।।14.12।।
slok12.transliteration: lobhaḥ pravṛttiḥ ārambhaḥ karmaṇām aśamaḥ spṛhā, rajasy etāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha
slok12.meaning: Greed, activity, undertaking of actions, restlessness, and desire—these arise when rajas is predominant, O best of the Bharatas.
slok12.explanation: Krishna lists rajas’ symptoms: greed, activity, restlessness, and desire. This sloka details rajas’ energetic nature. For Arjuna, rajas may drive his ambition or aggression in war, but recognizing these as guna-driven urges him to transcend them, fighting with detachment, dedicated to Krishna rather than personal gain.

slok13.sanskrit: अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च। तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन।।14.13।।
slok13.transliteration: aprakāśo ’pravṛttiś ca pramādo moha eva ca, tamasy etāni jāyante vivṛddhe kuru-nandana
slok13.meaning: Darkness, inertia, heedlessness, and delusion—these arise when tamas is predominant, O joy of the Kurus.
slok13.explanation: Krishna describes tamas’ symptoms: ignorance, inactivity, negligence, and delusion. This sloka outlines tamas’ obstructive effects. For Arjuna, tamas may manifest as confusion or reluctance in battle, urging him to cultivate sattva and transcend all gunas, ensuring his warrior duties are performed with clarity and divine focus.

slok14.sanskrit: यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत्। तदोत्तमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यति।।14.14।।
slok14.transliteration: yadā sattve pravṛddhe tu pralayaṁ yāti deha-bhṛt, tadottamavidāṁ lokān amalān pratipadyati
slok14.meaning: If the embodied one dies when sattva is predominant, they attain the pure worlds of those who know the highest.
slok14.explanation: Krishna explains that dying in sattva leads to higher, pure realms. This sloka discusses the afterlife based on guna dominance. For Arjuna, this motivates cultivating sattva in battle to ensure a higher destiny, yet he must transcend even sattva to achieve liberation, fighting with devotion to Krishna beyond material realms.

slok15.sanskrit: रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते। तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते।।14.15।।
slok15.transliteration: rajasi pralayaṁ gatvā karma-saṅgiṣu jāyate, tathā pralīnas tamasi mūḍha-yoniṣu jāyate
slok15.meaning: Dying in rajas, one is born among those attached to action; dying in tamas, one is born in deluded wombs.
slok15.explanation: Krishna states that death in rajas leads to rebirth among action-driven beings, and in tamas, among the deluded. This sloka continues the afterlife discussion. For Arjuna, this warns that rajas-driven or tamas-driven actions in war could bind him to lower rebirths, urging him to transcend gunas, fighting as a liberated soul devoted to Krishna.

slok16.sanskrit: कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम्। रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम्।।14.16।।
slok16.transliteration: karmaṇaḥ sukṛtasyāhuḥ sāttvikaṁ nirmalaṁ phalam, rajasas tu phalaṁ duḥkham ajñānaṁ tamasaḥ phalam
slok16.meaning: The fruit of good actions is said to be sattvic and pure; the fruit of rajas is pain; the fruit of tamas is ignorance.
slok16.explanation: Krishna describes the fruits of actions: sattva yields purity, rajas yields pain, and tamas yields ignorance. This sloka connects gunas to action’s outcomes. For Arjuna, this teaches that sattvic actions in war yield clarity, but rajas and tamas bring suffering or ignorance, urging him to act with sattva and transcend all gunas for liberation.

slok17.sanskrit: सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च। प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च।।14.17।।
slok17.transliteration: sattvāt sañjāyate jñānaṁ rajaso lobha eva ca, pramāda-mohau tamaso bhavato ’jñānam eva ca
slok17.meaning: From sattva arises knowledge, from rajas greed, and from tamas heedlessness, delusion, and ignorance.
slok17.explanation: Krishna links sattva to knowledge, rajas to greed, and tamas to delusion and ignorance. This sloka clarifies the gunas’ mental effects. For Arjuna, this helps identify war-related emotions—wisdom, ambition, or confusion—as guna-driven, urging him to foster sattva and transcend all gunas, ensuring his actions align with Krishna’s wisdom.

slok18.sanskrit: ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः। जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः।।14.18।।
slok18.transliteration: ūrdhvaṁ gacchanti sattva-sthā madhye tiṣṭhanti rājasāḥ, jaghanya-guṇa-vṛtti-sthā adho gacchanti tāmasāḥ
slok18.meaning: Those in sattva ascend upward, those in rajas remain in the middle, and those in tamas, abiding in the lowest qualities, descend downward.
slok18.explanation: Krishna describes the destinies influenced by gunas: sattva leads upward, rajas keeps one in the middle, and tamas leads downward. This sloka outlines spiritual evolution. For Arjuna, this motivates cultivating sattva in battle to ascend spiritually, yet transcending all gunas ensures liberation, guiding his warrior duties toward Krishna’s divine state.

slok19.sanskrit: नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति। गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति।।14.19।।
slok19.transliteration: nānyaṁ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṁ yadā draṣṭānupaśyati, guṇebhyaś ca paraṁ vetti mad-bhāvaṁ so ’dhigacchati
slok19.meaning: When the seer perceives no doer other than the gunas and knows what is beyond the gunas, they attain My nature.
slok19.explanation: Krishna explains that realizing the gunas as the doer and knowing the self beyond them leads to his divine nature. This sloka emphasizes transcendence. For Arjuna, this means seeing war actions as guna-driven, not soul-driven, enabling him to fight as a transcendent soul, attaining Krishna’s nature through detached devotion.

slok20.transliteration: guṇān etān atītya trīn dehī deha-samudbhavān, janma-mṛtyu-jarā-duḥkhair vimukto ’mṛtam aśnuti
slok20.meaning: Transcending these three gunas, which arise from the body, the embodied one, freed from birth, death, old age, and sorrow, attains immortality.
slok20.explanation: Krishna states that transcending the gunas liberates one from samsara’s miseries, granting immortality. This sloka highlights the goal of transcendence. For Arjuna, transcending gunas in battle frees him from the war’s emotional burdens, ensuring his warrior duties lead to liberation, as a soul unbound by material existence.

slok21.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। कैर्लिङ्गैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतानतीतो भवति प्रभो। किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तति।।14.21।।
slok21.transliteration: arjuna uvāca kair liṅgais trīn guṇān etān atīto bhavati prabho, kim ācāraḥ kathaṁ caitāṁs trīn guṇān ativartati
slok21.meaning: Arjuna said: By what signs is one known to have transcended these three gunas, O Lord? What is their conduct, and how do they transcend these three gunas?
slok21.explanation: Arjuna asks for the signs, conduct, and method of transcending the gunas. This sloka shifts focus to practical transcendence. For Arjuna, this question seeks guidance to rise above war-driven emotions, ensuring his warrior actions reflect a transcendent state, aligned with Krishna’s teachings for liberation.

slok22.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव। न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति।।14.22।।
slok22.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca prakāśaṁ ca pravṛttiṁ ca moham eva ca pāṇḍava, na dveṣṭi sampravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati
slok22.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: One who does not hate illumination, activity, or delusion when they arise, nor longs for them when they cease, O Pandava,
slok22.explanation: Krishna begins describing the signs of transcendence: indifference to the gunas’ effects—knowledge, action, or delusion. This sloka outlines emotional neutrality. For Arjuna, this means neither resenting nor craving war’s clarity, zeal, or confusion, enabling him to fight with equanimity, transcending guna-driven reactions for spiritual freedom.

slok23.sanskrit: उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते। गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येवं योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गति।।14.23।।
slok23.transliteration: udāsīnavad āsīno guṇair yo na vicālyate, guṇā vartanta ity evaṁ yo ’vatiṣṭhati neṅgati
slok23.meaning: One who sits like an indifferent spectator, unmoved by the gunas, knowing that the gunas alone act, and remains steady, unwavering,
slok23.explanation: Krishna continues, describing the transcendent as an impartial observer, unmoved by gunas, recognizing them as the doer. This sloka emphasizes detachment. For Arjuna, this means observing war’s events as guna-driven, remaining steady, enabling him to fight as a detached soul, unwavering in devotion to Krishna.

slok24.transliteration: sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ svasthaḥ sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ, tulya-priyāpriyo dhīras tulya-nindātma-saṁstutiḥ
slok24.meaning: Equal in pleasure and pain, self-contained, viewing a clod, stone, or gold alike, steady, equal to the pleasant and unpleasant, praise and blame,
slok24.explanation: Krishna lists further signs: equanimity in opposites, indifference to material value, and neutrality to praise or blame. This sloka highlights balanced perception. For Arjuna, this equanimity in war’s gains and losses, or praise and criticism, ensures he fights steadily, devoted to Krishna, unaffected by external judgments or outcomes.

slok25.sanskrit: मानावमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः। सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते।।14.25।।
slok25.transliteration: mānāvamānayos tulyas tulyo mitrāri-pakṣayoḥ, sarvārambha-parityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa ucyate
slok25.meaning: Equal in honor and dishonor, equal to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings, such a one is said to have transcended the gunas.
slok25.explanation: Krishna concludes the signs: neutrality in honor, relationships, and renunciation of initiatives, marking guna transcendence. This sloka defines the transcendent state. For Arjuna, this means treating allies and enemies equally in war, renouncing personal motives, ensuring his warrior duties are selfless acts of devotion, free from guna influence.

slok26.sanskrit: मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवति। स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान्ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते।।14.26।।
slok26.transliteration: māṁ ca yo ’vyabhicāreṇa bhakti-yogena sevati, sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahma-bhūyāya kalpate
slok26.meaning: One who serves Me with unswerving devotion through Bhakti Yoga transcends these gunas and is fit to become Brahman.
slok26.explanation: Krishna teaches that unwavering devotion to him through bhakti yoga enables transcendence of the gunas, leading to Brahman. This sloka emphasizes bhakti’s role. For Arjuna, this assures that fighting with devotion to Krishna transcends war’s guna-driven emotions, aligning his duties with the path to divine realization and liberation.

slok27.sanskrit: ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च। शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च।।14.27।।
slok27.transliteration: brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāham amṛtasyāvyayasya ca, śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca
slok27.meaning: For I am the foundation of Brahman, the immortal and imperishable, of eternal dharma, and of absolute bliss.
slok27.explanation: Krishna concludes Chapter 14, declaring himself as the basis of Brahman, eternal dharma, and ultimate bliss. This sloka establishes his supreme position. For Arjuna, this reinforces that devotion to Krishna in battle connects him to the eternal, ensuring his warrior duties lead to immortality, dharma, and bliss, transcending the gunas’ limitations.
